trans-unit.source: Types of risk events detected by Azure Active Directory Identity Protection | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Types of risk events detected by Azure Active Directory Identity Protection | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: This topic gives you a detailed overview of the available types of risk events in Azure Active Directory Identity Protection
trans-unit.target: This topic gives you a detailed overview of the available types of risk events in Azure Active Directory Identity Protection

trans-unit.source: Types of risk events detected by Azure Active Directory Identity Protection
trans-unit.target: Types of risk events detected by Azure Active Directory Identity Protection

trans-unit.source: In Azure Active Directory Identity Protection, risk events are events that:
trans-unit.target: In Azure Active Directory Identity Protection, risk events are events that:

trans-unit.source: were flagged as suspicious
trans-unit.target: were flagged as suspicious

trans-unit.source: indicate that an identity may have been compromised.
trans-unit.target: indicate that an identity may have been compromised.

trans-unit.source: This topic gives you a detailed overview of the available types of risk events.
trans-unit.target: This topic gives you a detailed overview of the available types of risk events.

trans-unit.source: Leaked credentials
trans-unit.target: Leaked credentials

trans-unit.source: Leaked credentials are found posted publicly in the dark web by Microsoft security researchers.
trans-unit.target: Leaked credentials are found posted publicly in the dark web by Microsoft security researchers.

trans-unit.source: These credentials are usually found in plain text.
trans-unit.target: These credentials are usually found in plain text.

trans-unit.source: They are checked against Azure AD credentials, and if there is a match, they are reported as “Leaked credentials” in Identity Protection.
trans-unit.target: They are checked against Azure AD credentials, and if there is a match, they are reported as “Leaked credentials” in Identity Protection.

trans-unit.source: Leaked credentials risk events are classified as a “High” severity risk event, because they provide a clear indication that the user name and password are available to an attacker.
trans-unit.target: Leaked credentials risk events are classified as a “High” severity risk event, because they provide a clear indication that the user name and password are available to an attacker.

trans-unit.source: Impossible travel to atypical locations
trans-unit.target: Impossible travel to atypical locations

trans-unit.source: This risk event type identifies two sign-ins originating from geographically distant locations, where at least one of the locations may also be atypical for the user, given past behavior.
trans-unit.target: This risk event type identifies two sign-ins originating from geographically distant locations, where at least one of the locations may also be atypical for the user, given past behavior.

trans-unit.source: In addition, the time between the two sign-ins is shorter than the time it would have taken the user to travel from the first location to the second, indicating that a different user is using the same credentials.
trans-unit.target: In addition, the time between the two sign-ins is shorter than the time it would have taken the user to travel from the first location to the second, indicating that a different user is using the same credentials.

trans-unit.source: This machine learning algorithm that ignores obvious "*false positives*" contributing to the impossible travel condition, such as VPNs and locations regularly used by other users in the organization.
trans-unit.target: This machine learning algorithm that ignores obvious "*false positives*" contributing to the impossible travel condition, such as VPNs and locations regularly used by other users in the organization.

trans-unit.source: The system has an initial learning period of 14 days during which it learns a new user’s sign-in behavior.
trans-unit.target: The system has an initial learning period of 14 days during which it learns a new user’s sign-in behavior.

trans-unit.source: Impossible travel is usually a good indicator that a hacker was able to successfully sign-in.
trans-unit.target: Impossible travel is usually a good indicator that a hacker was able to successfully sign-in.

trans-unit.source: However, false-positives may occur when a user is traveling using a new device or using a VPN that is typically not used by other users in the organization.
trans-unit.target: However, false-positives may occur when a user is traveling using a new device or using a VPN that is typically not used by other users in the organization.

trans-unit.source: Another source of false-positives is applications that incorrectly pass server IPs as client IPs, which may give the appearance of sign-ins taking place from the data center where that application’s back-end is hosted (often these are Microsoft datacenters, which may give the appearance of sign-ins taking place from Microsoft owned IP addresses).
trans-unit.target: Another source of false-positives is applications that incorrectly pass server IPs as client IPs, which may give the appearance of sign-ins taking place from the data center where that application’s back-end is hosted (often these are Microsoft datacenters, which may give the appearance of sign-ins taking place from Microsoft owned IP addresses).

trans-unit.source: As a result of these false-positives, the risk level for this risk event is “**Medium**”.
trans-unit.target: As a result of these false-positives, the risk level for this risk event is “**Medium**”.

trans-unit.source: Sign-ins from infected devices
trans-unit.target: Sign-ins from infected devices

trans-unit.source: This risk event type identifies sign-ins from devices infected with malware, that are known to actively communicate with a bot server.
trans-unit.target: This risk event type identifies sign-ins from devices infected with malware, that are known to actively communicate with a bot server.

trans-unit.source: This is determined by correlating IP addresses of the user’s device against IP addresses that were in contact with a bot server.
trans-unit.target: This is determined by correlating IP addresses of the user’s device against IP addresses that were in contact with a bot server.

trans-unit.source: This risk event identifies IP addresses, not user devices.
trans-unit.target: This risk event identifies IP addresses, not user devices.

trans-unit.source: If several devices are behind a single IP address, and only some are controlled by a bot network, sign-ins from other devices my trigger this event unnecessarily, which is the reason for classifying this risk event as “**Low**”.
trans-unit.target: If several devices are behind a single IP address, and only some are controlled by a bot network, sign-ins from other devices my trigger this event unnecessarily, which is the reason for classifying this risk event as “**Low**”.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you contact the user and scan all the user's devices.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you contact the user and scan all the user's devices.

trans-unit.source: It is also possible that a user's personal device is infected, or as mentioned earlier, that someone else was using an infected device from the same IP address as the user.
trans-unit.target: It is also possible that a user's personal device is infected, or as mentioned earlier, that someone else was using an infected device from the same IP address as the user.

trans-unit.source: Infected devices are often infected by malware that have not yet been identified by anti-virus software, and may also indicate as bad user habits that may have caused the device to become infected.
trans-unit.target: Infected devices are often infected by malware that have not yet been identified by anti-virus software, and may also indicate as bad user habits that may have caused the device to become infected.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to address malware infections, see the [Malware Protection Center](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=335773&clcid=0x409).
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to address malware infections, see the [Malware Protection Center](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=335773&clcid=0x409).

trans-unit.source: Sign-ins from anonymous IP addresses
trans-unit.target: Sign-ins from anonymous IP addresses

trans-unit.source: This risk event type identifies users who have successfully signed in from an IP address that has been identified as an anonymous proxy IP address.
trans-unit.target: This risk event type identifies users who have successfully signed in from an IP address that has been identified as an anonymous proxy IP address.

trans-unit.source: These proxies are used by people who want to hide their device’s IP address, and may be used for malicious intent.
trans-unit.target: These proxies are used by people who want to hide their device’s IP address, and may be used for malicious intent.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you immediately contact the user to verify if they were using anonymous IP addresses.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you immediately contact the user to verify if they were using anonymous IP addresses.

trans-unit.source: The risk level for this risk event type is “**Medium**” because in itself an anonymous IP is not a strong indication of an account compromise.
trans-unit.target: The risk level for this risk event type is “**Medium**” because in itself an anonymous IP is not a strong indication of an account compromise.

trans-unit.source: Sign-ins from IP addresses with suspicious activity
trans-unit.target: Sign-ins from IP addresses with suspicious activity

trans-unit.source: This risk event type identifies IP addresses from which a high number of failed sign-in attempts were seen, across multiple user accounts, over a short period of time.
trans-unit.target: This risk event type identifies IP addresses from which a high number of failed sign-in attempts were seen, across multiple user accounts, over a short period of time.

trans-unit.source: This matches traffic patterns of IP addresses used by attackers, and is a strong indicator that accounts are either already or are about to be compromised.
trans-unit.target: This matches traffic patterns of IP addresses used by attackers, and is a strong indicator that accounts are either already or are about to be compromised.

trans-unit.source: This is a machine learning algorithm that ignores obvious "*false-positives*", such as IP addresses that are regularly used by other users in the organization.
trans-unit.target: This is a machine learning algorithm that ignores obvious "*false-positives*", such as IP addresses that are regularly used by other users in the organization.

trans-unit.source: The system has an initial learning period of 14 days where it learns the sign-in behavior of a new user and new tenant.
trans-unit.target: The system has an initial learning period of 14 days where it learns the sign-in behavior of a new user and new tenant.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you contact the user to verify if they actually signed in from an IP address that was marked as suspicious.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you contact the user to verify if they actually signed in from an IP address that was marked as suspicious.

trans-unit.source: The risk level for this event type is “**Medium**” because several devices may be behind the same IP address, while only some may be responsible for the suspicious activity.
trans-unit.target: The risk level for this event type is “**Medium**” because several devices may be behind the same IP address, while only some may be responsible for the suspicious activity.

trans-unit.source: Sign-in from unfamiliar locations
trans-unit.target: Sign-in from unfamiliar locations

trans-unit.source: This risk event type is a real-time sign-in evaluation mechanism that considers past sign-in locations (IP, Latitude / Longitude and ASN) to determine new / unfamiliar locations.
trans-unit.target: This risk event type is a real-time sign-in evaluation mechanism that considers past sign-in locations (IP, Latitude / Longitude and ASN) to determine new / unfamiliar locations.

trans-unit.source: The system stores information about previous locations used by a user, and considers these “familiar” locations.
trans-unit.target: The system stores information about previous locations used by a user, and considers these “familiar” locations.

trans-unit.source: The risk even is triggered when the sign-in occurs from a location that's not already in the list of familiar locations.
trans-unit.target: The risk even is triggered when the sign-in occurs from a location that's not already in the list of familiar locations.

trans-unit.source: The system has an initial learning period of 14 days, during which it does not flag any new locations as unfamiliar locations.
trans-unit.target: The system has an initial learning period of 14 days, during which it does not flag any new locations as unfamiliar locations.

trans-unit.source: The system also ignores sign-ins from familiar devices, and locations that are geographically close to a familiar location.
trans-unit.target: The system also ignores sign-ins from familiar devices, and locations that are geographically close to a familiar location.

trans-unit.source: Unfamiliar locations can provide a strong indication that an attacker is able attempting to use a stolen identity.
trans-unit.target: Unfamiliar locations can provide a strong indication that an attacker is able attempting to use a stolen identity.

trans-unit.source: False-positives may occur when a user is traveling, trying out a new device or uses a new VPN.
trans-unit.target: False-positives may occur when a user is traveling, trying out a new device or uses a new VPN.

trans-unit.source: As a result of these false positives, the risk level for this event type is “**Medium**”.
trans-unit.target: As a result of these false positives, the risk level for this event type is “**Medium**”.

trans-unit.source: See also
trans-unit.target: See also

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory Identity Protection
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory Identity Protection
